extractions.description: In this paper, the authors address the problem of optimal control in decentralized linear quadratic systems with both major and minor agents, under the presence of non-Gaussian noise. Specifically, they characterize the structure of the optimal strategy and the best linear strategy for both types of agents. The results show how the optimal control actions and estimations can be achieved even when facing non-Gaussian noise, providing both theoretical insights and practical algorithms for implementation in systems like unmanned aerial vehicles and robotics.

type.justification: The paper focuses on characterizing the structure of optimal strategies and theoretical proofs for decentralized control systems under non-Gaussian noise.
type.quote: In this paper, we investigate a decentralized control system with a major agent and a collection of minor agents. The agents are coupled in their dynamics as well as cost.

name.justification: The paper discusses replacing the MMSE estimate with the LLMS (Linear Least Mean Squares) estimate as the best linear strategy under non-Gaussian noise conditions.
name.quote: Since the noise is non-Gaussian, the minor agent’s MMSE estimate is a non-linear function of its observation. It is shown that replacing the minor agent’s MMSE estimate by its LLMS (linear least mean square) estimate gives the best linear control strategy.

is_compared.justification: LLMS is compared to other estimators like MMSE in terms of performance under non-Gaussian noise.
is_compared.quote: In summary, in centralized control of linear quadratic systems with non-Gaussian noise, there is a two-way separation of estimation and control; the optimal control action is a linear function of the MMSE estimate of the state given the data at the controller. The best linear controller has the same structure except the MMSE estimate of the state is replaced by the LLMS estimate.
